Setting Brushes and Exploring What They Do

Mixed Brush Digital Sketchbook

  • 7.5 x 7.5 Inches @ 300 dpi

  • Corel Painter Essentials 4

  • Wacom Cintiq wx12

One of several explorations I’ve been playing with recently just to become more familiar with the brushes and settings in Corel Painter Essentials 4.  I like some of the possibilities I’ve found in this.  From here I may attempt other work. I also use Photoshop Elements 6 so at this point I’m likely to combine the two when working on a project.

Haiga with Digital Ink

silent night

the grass grows taller

with each song note

Digital Ink

  • 8 x 8 Inches @300 dpi

  • Corel Painter Essentials 4

  • Adobe Photoshop Elements 6

  • Wacom Cintiq 12wx

Playing with brushes with Corel Painter Essentials 4 lead me to a point where I wanted to experiment with what I’m here calling Digital Ink.  The above Haiga is one of the first works in this way.  I had thought I’d post it in December because of the subject connections of course – yes, even in December I have to mow the yard were I live. . .

In reading MLA’s Red Dragonfly Blog and her Haikuverse No. 2 (#9),  I encountered Marlene Mountain’s Ink Writings.  As a result I decided to heck with December, I should have posted already.  bwahahahahaha. Life. . . May be I will call these Digital Ink Haiga – Ink-ku. bwahahahahahaha. Fun.

*Revised Version:

Haiga with Digital Ink - Revised

silent night

the grass grows taller

with each note

One of the advantages with Digital Work is the ability to alter and revise.  At this point I prefer this version. Do you have a preference?

blossoms fall

on the ground

the silent snow

~

Haiga is Image with Haiku

  • 5.5 x 5.75 Inches

Self Portrait with Button

Would This Portrait Inspire You To Haiku?


“What portraits inspire you to haiku?” – a question asked by Margaret Dornaus on her blog Haiku-doodle under Art Lessons…

A portrait connected with nature is most likely to inspire me into haiku.  However in response to the question Margaret asked I found it fun to haiku into the portrait of a human being as inspiration as well.

 

 

Self Portrait with Button and Haiku - Haiga

rain beard

worn on his face

a storm

 

 

Portrait and Haiku - Haiga

portrait

each raindrop a note

in the storm

Christmas in Hawaii

  • Digital Drawing and Painting

This is a fun way to play with multiple ideas; from haiga and haiku to a copyright stamp for the new year and the idea that Christmas can be expressed in a variety of ways.  Of course fun is always a plus.

With haiga i try to create a visual balance between image and words so that one is as easy to go to and see as the other and the placement of each relates in some way with the placement of the other.

Digital Sketchbooks are fun.  Playing to explore ideas and materials in a spontaneous way often leads to interesting thoughts.  This page is from a couple of months ago when i was exploring what i’ve called digital ink.  Looking back at something like this gives me ideas and directions i might pursue in new work. It’s fun to push my own boundaries in new ways.

*A note to those who play in ku-me: Ku On This is not replacing ku-me – yet.

Title: I’m Posting every day way i think i am able to in 2011 with the goal of improving on last year! yeah. that’s my goal.

 

An Altered Image with an Altering Ku - Haiga

altered note

written with quill

grass stains

I’ve decided i want intend to blog more than last year. Rather than just think about doing it, I’m doing it, and starting right now.  I will be posting to this blog once a day / once a week as often as possible which i’m hoping will at least average out to more than a few times a week for all of 2011.

I know it won’t be easy, but it might it will be fun, because that’s how i intend to make it, inspiring, because i like collaboration and working within my own way at blogging, awesome, because that is what i’m aiming for, and wonderful, because, heck, who else wonders like i do? Therefore I’m promising myself to will make use of The DailyPost, and the community of other bloggers with similar goals, in any way i am able to conceive, to help me (as well as you and us) along the way. Including asking for help when I need it and encouraging others when I can.

If you already ready my blog (or join in at any time), I hope you’ll encourage me with comments and likes, and good will along the way - and especially play with my play, explore within and outside of the box of our thinking and you know… have fun.

Signed,

Rick Daddario and sometimes Wrick, which i go by at times on the net.

p.s. okay, yeah sometimes i over tweak. and sometimes i ramble a lot. i  like creating images and playing. so… a new post will almost always be – yeah, new.  and yeah. fun.  here’s an image i’m working on:

 

An Idea of Place, Space, Sanctuary and Awe

An altered photo from images i’ve taken in Hawaii.

Hau’oli Makahiki Hou!

(Happy New Year!)

Mahalo (Thanks) WordPress, the DailyPost and you my readers,  for a great blogging experience – aloha – Wrick

New Year's Eve 2011

celebration

above the house

New Year’s Eve

Altered Photo

  • 8 x 12 Inches @ 300 ppi

Yes, this photo was taken shortly after midnight, January 1, 2011.  Fireworks are a big part of the New Year’s Celebration in Hawaii.  Think of a fireworks display that you’ve seen go off on the 4th of July if you live in the USA.  Then imagine that kind of display going off in front of may be 60 to 70% of the houses on every street in  your neighborhood.  Now you probably have a reasonable idea of New Year’s Eve in Hawaii.  …or at least in this neighborhood.  Ka-boom.  …and then most of the time they clean the left over debris all up.

Look Look A Page In A Merry-Go-Round Book

 

An Active Reader: Spinning The Book To Read

  • Digital Drawing and Painting

  • 8.5 x 8.5 Inches @ 300 ppi

For a moment there I thought it might be fun to spin the book to read the story.  Okay, okay, I’m playing. again. The story in this case is written as I create and spin the page.  It goes on until I get to where I need to stop.  That becomes the end.  In a sense it’s like shot-gun writing with space as a limiting factor, it becomes as it is in the moment of writing. fun.

yeah, it happens.  life.  six days into the year and i cant keep up already. so if i cant dance i might as well fly. yeah, i’m going with the flow and fly.  up.  that’s what slipping up is about, yes?  flying.

i have two questions for you if you feel like chirping in:

okay, for Q counters that was more than two Qs.  i oops up like that sometimes.  life.

This Sky Dance

A small mixed media work from 2010.  i thought of this work because yesterday (Sunday) i went down to the beach and drew in the sand.  that’s what artists do, they create with what is around them.  …okay, i went down to the sea knowing i intended to draw in the sand because i took along a stick i like to draw with in the sand and my camera.  i didnt photograph sky birds but i did take some shots of a Brazilian Cardinal.  so i had birds in my skull along with the sea and i remembered this work.  currently  – or should i say slowly – i’m exploring on some “key” mixed media works that are slightly smaller than this that visually – at this point –  have a similar feel.

 

A Dance of Wings

Sea of Wings

(©2010)

A Blossom Field

A couple of days ago with some friends, I watched Golden Plovers – the visitors that fly down (and back) from Alaska each year.   There was a high cloud covering and the day was pleasantly warm.  The sea was close enough to hear at times.  One field we were in was an open space at the side of a dirt road – a cool place to Ku On This…

A 30 - 50 Foot Sea Slide

big wave rider

thirty seconds down a thousand tons

of water

Altered Photograph

  • 12 x 8 Inches @ 300 ppi
  • Nikon CoolPix 8700 Digital Camera
  • Adobe Photoshop Elements 6
  • Wacom Cintiq 12wx

The waves werent big enough – yet – a few days ago.  The Eddie Aikau (The Quiksilver In Memory of Eddie Aikau) has till the end of February to run.  The event takes place on one day if the waves are right.  Some years the waves are not big enough or not consistently big enough.  Since 1984-85 the best-in-the-world-by-invitation-only event has been completed eight times.  It may make it this year – you can watch and see if it does online.  A few days ago it almost ran.   Take a look at some of the videos and read the story of Eddie Aikau – the friend and courage that makes a legend.

the long drop

down a skyscraper sea

big wave riders

Bringing together various materials like this is fun.  I saw some heart cards that Artimagica (Kathleen Hendrick) was doing the other day – she has several posts dedicated to them. As I’ve periodically played with cards in various formats for various purposes I decided to create a Valentine’s Day Card for the Zazzle Shop I think I may be building.  I say I think I may be building, because it looks like it’ll be one work at a time.  Hopefully it will be works that have a long term range of functionality.  The Zazzle Note Card – which this is intended for happens to be 5 x 7 Inches so in this case I can also make Digital ACEOs (Art Cards, Editions and Originals) from the same work.  The Zazzle Note Card has 4 areas in which I can work, this would be the cover.  I’ll see where the card might go after this…

Haiku Caption Title Comment Short Story or Ask

Yeah, my studio is my way.  This is actually circa 2008 in my studio. Today it has several more layers and the passage ways are a little more challenging.  Still… it works for me and I like it this way.  The additional photo below is three different views of my two studio spaces.   That’s still the computer I use (in the lower right image) but the Cintiq is not there, yet.  There are a number of other views of my studios that I’ve taken over time – all with varying degrees of chaos that I work well in and enjoy.

The thinking for Ku On This #005-2011 is due to several recent blog conversations/comments.  Actually doing it is probably mostly a result of Benedicte Delachanal’s Blog Carnet De Dessins and her post here.

I’ve found that some of my blog readers have been hesitant to join in on Ku On This – for various reasons.  So i’m going to open it up a bit with some other comment options.  Yeah, by all means Haiku – or Caption, Title, Comment, Short Story or Ask a Question – it all works and it’s all fun.  So Ku On This…

Bottles With Butterflies

(©2009)

Altered Photograph

  • 8 x 10 Inches @ 300 ppi

  • Digital Photograph

  • Digital Drawing and Painting

  • Nikon D80 Camera

  • Adobe Photoshop Elements 6

There was a time when I’d paint all kinds of things – including bottles – with white gesso paint.  Mostly that was to help people see shapes and shadows although I use these things for my own projects and works in other ways as well.   I had drawn a butterfly with digital technology – using a mouse at that time for my drawing tool – which was fun even if it was a challenge.   These butterfly variations were used in a variety of ways, including as embellishing stamps I’d add to Mail Art Envelopes (and still do at times).  One night I got to thinking about the labels on bottles while playing with the word sounds of Bottles-With-Butterflies. I liked the sound of the words together – like a fluttering in my mind.  After a time I began thinking about the ancient bottles that are sometimes found in archeological explorations.   That led me to another  thought: What if I could open up some mysterious old bottles and pour out all of these flying butterflies.  You can see what happened with that thought in the photograph above – Fun – the possibilities of fun.

This post was inspired by Chris Carter’s comment on one of her posts that “Bottles and jars provide infinite possibilities.” Yeah, I agree Chris – some really great possibilities. Thanks.

Some variations on a Butterfly with digital technology…

In 2007 – 2009 I was still using a mouse as a drawing tool in Photoshop.  Printed up these Artist Embellishing Stamps are each about 1.25 x 1.25 Inches Square.

In 2007/08, in one of the mail art communities where I am a member, we each created our own Skinny Alphabet Book as a group project.  Each week at random a letter was chosen along with a technique or concept that we then used to create our page.  I used Digital Technology to create my pages.

Is this the spirit of Enso?

Sometimes I find a fallen bird nest in the yard.  A bird nest is such an amazing thing to discover.  Sometimes I look around to see if there is someone near by because I want to share the discovery, “Come look. A bird nest”.  No matter how they are constructed I find them fascinating.

Do you see the master builder’s Enso in this nest?  Caption, Title, Comment, Short Story, Ask or

A Challenging Lawn To Mow?

In Issa’s Untidy Hut (The Poetry Blog for Lilliput Review) this past Wednesday, Don Wentworth connected up the Wednesday Haiku by Ed Markowski to one of Issa’s haiku which contained the line “thick summer grasses” as translated by David G. Lanoue.  I had fun in the comments there at Issa’s Untidy Hut and discovered a number of things – or remembered I once new some things too… One of those remembered things had to do with bamboo.  Periodically I photograph bamboo for various reasons, so I thought this week it might be fun to Ku On This:

The Ways of Issa's Thick Grass

Bamboo in Sunlight and Shadow

Over the last few weeks people have found more and more ways in which to respond to Ku On This.  I like that.  This week once again I’m adding to the list of ways you might respond – and to be clear – these are not the only ways..  Please Caption, Title, Comment, Short Story, Ask, Draw, Paint or Ku On This in any way you’d like to explore.  If you can not leave your response (such as a drawing or a painting) in a comment, be sure to leave a link – it’s more fun that way. Mahalo (Thank you) – have fun – Aloha.

Unknowingly Getting To Where I’m Going

A Quick Sketch From Skull Memory

Two Sounding Stones On A Box

Music All Around

Small Sketchbook Drawing (Canson Field Sketch Book 10 x 7 Inches)

  • 5.25 x 2.25 Inches

  • Graphite on Paper (Actually it’s an ever-sharp – automatic pencil? – .5mm – you can find these in most any store with writing implements – it’s probably about an HB hardness.)

  • Tortillion (Sometimes called a smudge stick)

I’d call this a thumbnail sketch but may be it’s a little too large for that… may be it’s more of a thumb (size) sketch?  The sketchbook is hard back and double wire bound.  I like double wire bound and hard back because the sketch book will fold all the way back and lay flat while I draw whether it is on a flat surface or hand held.

In late January for some reason I began to do a sketch each day after writing in what I began calling my “yard journal”.   The yard journal was something I’ve wanted to do for years and finally started last November.  For years I’d been keeping little scraps of paper noting when I spot a new blossom or bud cluster or something sprouting or when I trim something… those kinds of things.    So I started the yard journal and then it stopped over the holidays.  Then it started back up again in January some time and then the daily sketches began – in a different place, a sketchbook.

I keep the sketchbook and yard journal along with the drawing and writing tools in a canvas bag an artist friend gave me several years ago. Some times a day will go by and I don’t write or draw in them, however I’ve begun to notice that I feel good when I do these little writings and drawings.  I like that.

The above sketch wasn’t the first.  It’s from a glancing look in my studio at some stones that are used to tap out a rhythm – similar to rhythm sticks.   The sketch is partly made up too, of course.  I like graphite but in a sketchbook it tends to smudge more than just where I smudge it.   I’ve switched over to pen and ink and water-brush now.  This sketch was near the start when I was just finding out what I might do in the sketchbook.  Sometimes that’s how things begin for me.  I just slip into them and then I find out where I’m going.  Does this kind of thing happen to you?

Initially I created fifteen of these small Shrine Works knowing I’d swap out at least nine of them.  These are three of my Shrine works for Peace.

A Backyard Sketchbook Drawing

Some Fun In February

A few moments of fun and sun with a lot of rain and the lime tree begins to bloom.

Each of the five petals from the blossoms of this tree fall separately from the bloom.  Sometimes there is quite a scattering of petals here and there beneath the tree.  When they catch my eye I often pause imagining that some small creature has lost it’s wings – which was my puzzled reaction the first time I noticed them.  Now I know what they are, but it’s still fun to play with the idea of white wings from a small creature.

As with many citrus trees the blossoms of this lime are fragrant.  Even the leaves have a pleasant scent and young leaves are a taste treat in salads and other dishes.  The air around this tree often makes me want to slow down, breath deep and relax for a few moments.  I like that.

I’m not really convinced this little drawing is great haiku material.  It would be fun to find that it is…  Have fun and Ku On This…

National Haiku Writing Month

(NaHaiWriMo)

February 2011

Haiku I’ve written this month – February 2011.  It’s not complete but it’s mostly here.  It’s a lot like any other month.

I’m reasonably serious about my haiku.  That means if I play and have fun with it I’m likely to do it the rest of my life.  However if I have to do it – yeah, it may be easier to get a mule to write haiku for me.

True: I did not commit to writing one haiku a day this month as encouraged to do by NaHaiWriMo.  That’s the way it works for me sometimes.

As of this writing I don’t have a Facebook account.  I’m not likely to get one – yet, as far as I can see – of course, I have no idea about tomorrow.  I would however like to share what I’ve written.

Re-writing is not something I do a lot – yet.  I tell myself I will re-write when the time comes – but really, I will probably do very little of it unless… okay, sometimes I do re-write.   These are mostly how they came out when I wrote them down plop and that’s it.  If they change some day, cool – and if they dont change – that’s okay too – at least for now.

Note: The date, number and other marks above each haiku are my way of referencing the day, file and original site or place etc. the haiku was written.

Between Daylight and Dark is a fascinating moment of transition.  When darkness begins, yet the sky is still relatively bright, house lights and street lights come on creating interesting patterns and reflections with light and shadow.  This photo was taken in one of those moments.

The photo looks into what i call an Orchid Closet which is off the kitchen window.  One side is the house.  One side, the one we are looking into is open.  The other two sides are made up of tall pickets.  The orchids are suspended in this broken light area.

The lights beyond the Orchid Closet are the house across the street. The light in front of the closet and on the house to the right are from the neighbor’s house which is about as far away as this house is to the fence.

Next to the Orchid Closet are the strawberry guava trees – all kept well below the roof line. This is also the side of the house were I keep my bonsai next to the fence (at the lower left of the photo).

The light, the setting and anything else this image might lead you to think about all create a great moment to…

Sunlight and Feathers in a Jar

A Digital Sketchbook Study ~ Which is also a finished work as it is of course.

Naked Mail Art ~ Study

  • 8 x 12 Inches @300 ppi
  • Digital Drawing and Painting
  • Scanned Watercolor
  • Adobe Photoshop Elements 6
  • Corel Painter Essentials 4
  • Epson Perfection 1650

This is essentially an idea I have at the moment for a Naked Mail Art swap.  Naked Mail Art (or Naked Mail) refers to art work or a thing that is sent through the postal service without being wrapped or placed in an envelope in the usual sense of sending something by mail.

In this case if it all works when I try it the way I’d like it to happen, I’ll suspend a small work inside a plastic peanut butter (or similar) jar.   The top of the jar will be permanently attached.  The address (or address labels) and stamps will then be placed directly on the jar.  As this is an idea at this point a lot could change as I begin working with the actual materials and process of creation.

As I’m currently envisioning it I do not know if the postal service will accept this work for delivery.  That of course is part of the fun – finding out if your art work can actually go through the postal service sans wrapping or envelope – that is, naked – for all the world to see on it’s travels.

Of course what happens to a work of this nature on it’s delivery route and how it arrives becomes part of the process the work goes through on the way to completion.   I call the stuff that accumulates in this stage of the process – Post Office Patina. Completion of the work as I see it, is upon arrival at it’s intended destination in what ever condition it’s in when it gets there.

This is one of the interactive formats of Mail Art.   Every thing that happens during the completion of this kind of art work is part of the attraction of Mail Art – and the fun.

  • 8 x 12 Inches @ 300 ppi
  • Nikon D80 Digital Camera

This is one of the rare times when I’ve used the photograph almost straight from my camera the way I initially took the photo.   There is some cropping, turning, and framing that I’ve done in Photoshop – plus the haiku of course.   So it is a slightly altered image.  Still… it’s mostly the way the image was originally  shot as I saw it in cement (concrete).

This is one of many images I’ve photographed recently.  I’m thinking of these as Fossils in Cement – or Sidewalk Fossils.  Essentially imprints in sidewalks where I walk.  In addition to these kind of images I’ve also been photographing things on and around the sidewalks.  It’s a lot of fun in most cases.  The images are at every step I take (almost), although I’m sure I will become more selective eventually.  My aim is to create a series of these and from that eventually a book.

Yes, again I’ve had people come out of their house and ask me what I’m doing.  When I explain, they have gotten excited about it.  This is a project I’ve contemplated for several years and I’m just now stepping into it to see where it might go.

Each of these postcards in Mail Art vernacular is considered to be Hand Drawing/Painting.  They were created at the same time.  Although they are similar, each is individually unique.

I use the word “of” (1 of 4 through 4 of 4) when numbering work of this nature to help distinguish it as different from prints which often use a slash in the numbering system (1/4 through 4/4) for work created at the same time and of the same edition.

This blog post is a response to a question in a comment from an earlier post in this blog from Linda Halcomb.  Thanks Linda. Clicking the four postcard image will bring up a slightly larger version of the postcards.

As verbose as I can be in comments at times it seems funny-odd when I dont know what to say about a work.  This is one of those works.  It is what it is.  Whew.  Now that I’ve said that, may be I will become my chattery self (yeah, I know chattery isnt a word. It just feels like it should be). 

Sometimes when I chatter about a work I find out what the work is actually about or doing.  Yeah, I dont always know where my work is going when I start out – I find out when I get there.  That’s one of the things I like to do.   I like to figure out what I am doing or thinking about or saying by getting there.  Sometimes I can do that by feeling my way through a process of creating.

This work pulls from a lot of different sources in my creative cabinet.  Past work.  Work I havnt shown yet.  Old ways.  New Ways.  Experiments.  And a few things I just like to do.  That’s often how I work of course.  It’s also reflective of me, the way I am and I think it’s also reflective of life.  I like that.  I like that being in my art.

One thing I’d like to point out is that the central area of this work is actually most of a smaller mixed media work that I recently completed and have not shown yet for reasons that are mostly obscure and typical of the way I am.  It’s altered considerably of course and in the context of this work it takes on a perspective that doesnt exist in the original work – which is why I used it here.  It’s one of five small mixed media works with “key” imagery that I will most likely show – eventually.

In some ways I see “Moving Into Place” as being similar to “Becoming” – which is what I think we all do with every choice we make.  In that sense I see this work as being about Becoming.

Elements Of Fascination

A Clay Slab

Aug. 20, 1979

Stoneware Cone 6 Electric Firing

  • 18.5 x 14 x 1 Inches
  • Approximate Weights: Wet 25 pounds – Fired 18-20 pounds
  • Garnet Schist (stone)
  • Glass
  • Slotted Bolts
  • Clay Attachments
  • Impressions
  • Ceramic Oxides
  • Glaze

A slab from my mud (clay) days.  It was made from one block of clay that came in a 20-25 pound unit.  The Garnet Schist is the pinkish stone in the lower left corner which is “strapped” in with clay and fired along with the slab.  The dark spots are garnets.  I found that stone in an area of Northern Idaho.

A lot of this slab is experimenting with ideas – like the strapped in stone.  The stone doesnt shrink like clay does when fired so creating enough space to allow for shrinkage around the stone was something I had to work out a bit.   There is brown glass broken and dropped into a scooped out area as well as ceramic oxide and glaze experimenting too.

Periodically during this time I made a number of these slabs. Some were tossed out (an experimental way of making a slab that I began using and finally using it almost exclusively – because it was just fun to do).  Some were rolled out between boards with a rolling pin – yeah, an extra big rolling pin.  Some were rolled out on a slab roller.

This slab was not worked after firing, which I have experimented with at times too, using among other things: acrylics, watercolor, shoe polish, oils, soil etc. 

Clay as a working material is almost endless in almost any state from wet clay to bisque ware and after glaze firing too.   It can be thin and translucent or thick, opaque and  heavy.  It can take on endless textures, forms or shapes.  The surface when fired can be as slick as glass, burnished and slightly porous or as rough as you’d like to leave it.  Adding slips to a surface creates other options as well.  It does take a studio area of it’s own or access to one.  It’s also a lot of fun.

I’ve added a smaller image of this slab to see if it helps with viewing from a slow net connection.

Stream ~ Small Streams and Dreams

(©2006)

Small (Very Small) Watercolor

  • 3 x 4 Inches (Approximately)
  • Permanent Water Soluble Ink
  • Watercolor
  • Arches 140# Hot Press Watercolor Paper
  • Torn and Cut Edges

Looking for this or that or something or other, I was rummaging through one of my infamous piles of things and came across this little work.  It caught me off guard and I saw it fresh as if having never seen it.  I liked it.  What fun I thought. What a great place to be I thought.

Evidently in 2006 I was doing some things like this.  Of course I will probably do things like this some more too – although I never really know.

I like when something I’ve forgotten shows up and surprises me into seeing it this way.  Of course I especially like it when I like what I see. 

The thing is I’m often too close to something when I first work on it to judge it with an objective fair eye.  I may be able to sense whether I’ll like it or not but that’s not the same thing as re-discovering it fresh and new and finding that I do things I like. 

Sometimes it takes me a while to know what I think or even exactly how I feel about something.

Anoles are sometimes confused with geckos although they are quite different in a number of ways.  Usually I find anoles outside and geckos inside although both at times are in either place.  Anole toes are usually more tapered and pointed where gecko toes are more rounded.  Anoles have the ability to adapt their coloration to simulate their surrounding environment.  As I understand it, the anole in this photograph is female.

This is the first of three parts on Mail Art work I created for the current Naked Postal Art swap (Naked Mail Art) taking place through one of the Mail Art communities where I am a member.  The work was completed and sent through the Postal Service about a week ago.  It recently arrived – which is why I am posting about it now.

The swap is with several Mail Art friends in one of the communities I’ve been active in at times.  Nervousness or Nness for short is not particularly active now although people still return to say hi and occasionally someone will organize a small swap there.  Many of the Mail Artists who were active on Nness have regrouped at ATCs For All and Art Forty-Two where I am also a member although not particularly active at this time.  If you are looking for advanced artists who work in Mail Art check out Illustrated ATCs – a sister site to ATCs For All.

A few weeks ago (March of 2011) I posted some thoughts on the current Naked Postal Art swap at Nness.  The working title referred to it as Naked Mail Art ~ Sunlight and Feathers in a Jar.  The final concept for my art work in this swap is similar although a number of changes were made and the final work is a little different.

In previous Naked Postal Art swaps I’ve sent bamboo through the post office. This time I decided to paint and send a bamboo forest –  in a jar.  Some bamboo that grows in my yard had been cut for another art project and as it was already dry I modified it to suit my forest concept.

A segment of green bamboo that was cut a few minutes before scanning it.  This segment would need to dry before I’d use it as intended for most projects.   Cutting and trimming  is easier when the bamboo is green.  When it’s dry it’s a little more difficult to cut however with some experimenting it worked out and I had the start of my bamboo forest.

The beginning of a bamboo forest painting cut to size for the jar I intended to use.

A white acrylic paint step for the bamboo forest painting.

Painting Bamboo Forest in a Jar Parts Two and Three (to follow in the next day or so) will include some of the things found in and around the bamboo forest as well as images of the finished work ready to mail.

It’s fun to work on this kind of project.  I encourage you to ask questions or comment at any time and also to explore the Mail Art sites mentioned in this post if you are curious or have an interest in Mail Art (I’m probably known as Wrick or Wrick19 on Mail Art sites).  

Have fun – aloha.

An Artist’s Skinny Alphabet Book was created as a Challenge, which in Mail Art terms is a way to expand experience and gain knowledge by exploring new techniques, ideas or imagery, rather than as a competitive exercise.  Although this ABC Skinny Book has yet to be printed up or published, it’s still fun to look through the pages on a computer.

One random letter per week was selected for the participating members of a Mail Art Community called Paper Traders within Yahoo Groups.  Along with the random letter each week, a specific technique, concept, idea or image was to be included or used in creating the page.   Occasionally I tweaked criteria to accommodate my Skinny Book which was created with digital technology as well as other work I created with additional materials.

The Letter M From An Artist's Skinny Alphabet Book

This is the second of three parts on Mail Art work I created for the current Naked Postal Art swap (Naked Mail Art) taking place through one of the Mail Art communities where I am a member.  The work was completed and sent through the Postal Service about a week prior to this posting.  It recently arrived – which is why I am posting about it now. 

The first part of this three part post.   The third part of this three part post.


On the top of the  jar lid is a digital drawing and painting which was processed as a photograph.  The lid was sealed in place so the jar which is a clear plastic can not be opened without breaking it.

As the bamboo forest came together I realized there were things that might be found in as well as around the forest including a postal label and title for the work.

In this image the addresses have been altered.  The addresses were clear enough for delivery of the jar to the recipient.  

Some of  the things in the jar are digital creations again processed as a photograph.  Other materials include acrylic, watercolor, ink and colored pencil on drawing and watercolor paper. 

Every thing in the jar is free to move around, sometimes seen, sometimes hidden depending on how the jar sits or is turned.  As the jar is transported these things may shift considerably within the bamboo forest which is part of the fun as I see it.

The final part to this three part post should be on the blog tomorrow.

This is the third and final post of three parts on Mail Art work I created for the current Naked Postal Art swap (Naked Mail Art) taking place through one of the Mail Art communities where I am a member (see the first post for links to some of these communities).  The work was completed and sent through the Postal Service about a week prior to this posting.  It recently arrived – which is why I am posting about it now. 

The (#1)  first of this three part post.     The (#2) second of this three part post.


The finished work with the title side showing prior to taking it to the post office.  Of course now what I call Post Office Patina has been added to the work as it traveled.  Most Mail Art Artists consider post office patina as part of the work.  Sometimes there are a few minor additions in the travel stage of the process and sometimes there is a lot of change.  It is fun to puzzle out or imagine how a bit of patina might have been added.


With each handling of the work the view of the bamboo forest can change.  I like that.

This is the finished work at the post office where I’ve added postal stamps.  I prefer postal stamps to metered tape so I usually ask specifically for stamps.  The addresses in this image have been altered.  Postal people could easily read where this work was going.  

The experience at the post office is part of Mail Art.  Sometimes it’s wild and fun, sometimes… not so much.  Most all Mail Art Artists that I know have stories about these experiences.  Mostly it’s great interaction with people and in this case I ended up getting one of my favorite post office counter people.  He made it easy and fun to be sending Mail Art via the post office. 

As a comment by Leslie pointed out – part of the fun is imagining and wondering about the reactions and interactions of postal workers (and others) who see, carry and experience Naked Postal Art Work first hand.

This is the final part to this three part post. 

To be clear, anyone can become involved in Mail Art.  When you create and exchange Mail Art you become a Mail Art Artist.  It’s easy to look into what is being done and begin to explore and interact with Mail Art communities.  Many of these communities extend around the planet via the internet.  That is a lot of the fun too.  All Mail Art is not as complex as this post has been.  Most Mail Art is simply way fun.

Running Thoughts Story:

a spring bamboo thought.  it’s windy. 

i loose brush color into a sketchbook and when it’s dry the rain begins to spatter the page.  in the semi-shelter of the eave i hold the pages of the sketchbook open, out of the rain.  mostly.  the bamboo bouncing.  the clouds break.  spots of sun and then rain again with the wind.

this happens sometimes.  i’m more rushed than i want to be.

the haiku isnt right.  the image isnt quite there in the way i want it to be there.  that’s okay, that just means i get to try again later.  a second page isnt quite right either but i’ve started a third on different paper.  sometimes it’s just fun to keep trying.

maybe:

This is an experimental writing within image work. 

Words and Image together as one work, I like that idea.  Haiga appeals to me.  At times I think of combining image and words into a longer work, such as story.  Although this is still a flash story it is much longer than haiku.

Because I’d like the story laid out as it is in the image I’m experimenting to see if it is reasonably readable within the image alone rather than add the story again below the work.

Let me know please if the story is impossible for you to read.

Yeah, I’m having fun with this.  aloha.

Yes, experimenting. Again. It has occurred to me that if I keep the story set in the image, in some ways the story becomes hidden – at least on line – because search engines can not find (if I understand it right) the words in the image.   The title of the post, yes, but not the story itself. 

Search engines will not pick up these image with story works as writing/story – although they might from tags I suppose.  In general I’d say that’s probably not what I should want.  It is the web after all. 

On the other side of that thought is the fun of a secret hidden some place on the net. 

Yeah, I’ll have to think about this. In some ways this kind of thing appeals to me although it also seems that I may be working against myself.  Curious.  We do that working against our self a lot I think. …at least I seem to…  at times.

May be it’s fun though, something yet to discover, uncover, a thousand years from now on the net.  A hidden thing.  I like that in some ways too.

Acrylic on Book Pages in an Altered Book

These pages are all slightly cropped.

I’ve gone through several versions of what I think this book is moving toward as a completed work.  On this page I wanted to see how ink would take on the acrylic.


Initially I laid paint on until the entire page as originally printed could not be seen.   Eventually I began to like the structure of the underlying text and began to allow more of the printed text to show through at times.

I consider these pages as background and intend to add to them once the backgrounds are complete.  Currently I am rethinking that slightly.  These pages may be closer to finished than I had initially thought they were at this stage.

Now a number of the pages have additions being added as I work the background.   I’m also likely to go back and alter some of the pages further to pull the book together once I see how the book as a whole is taking form.  In that sense I consider these pages a work in progress rather than completed, although of course it is not absolutely necessary that the entire book be about any one thing.  At this time I’m about half way through the book with these backgrounds and backgrounds with additions.

The book itself and thoughts on Altering a book:

  • The closed hardback book itself is about 5.75 x 8.75 inches.  The pages are slightly smaller.  The workable area of an open spread in this book is about 10 x 8.5 inches.

Altered Book Projects are embraced by many Mail Art artists.  Books tend to be small enough to easily go through the Postal Service.  Books themselves are a treasure.  Altered Books tend to become even more treasured.

For those new to Altered Books it may initially be a challenge to get past the idea of reworking a book – Yikes! You’re Doing What!?! To A Book?.   If this is similar to your reaction consider some of the books you can choose to give new life:

  • Discarded and Outdated Books of which there are tremendous numbers in existence so that it is likely that an original version can always be found.

  • Damaged and Missing-Page Books that can no longer be read or used functionally as originally intended.

  • Over Printed Books which are other wise returned to Publishing Houses or Printers to be destroyed – literally thousands a year.  …Although this is probably better now in this age of Printing-On-Demand, Web-Readers and eBooks.

Keeping some of this in mind when choosing a book to alter makes the idea of Altering Books a good and easily obtainable option for unique Journals, Themed Sketchbooks, Sculptures and 3-Dimensional works and all kinds of other creativity.  An Altered Book becomes a one-of-a-kind original work and can most likely last as long as the book itself would, yet with an Altered and Renewed Life.

Book Pages with Acrylic Paint and (Reasonably)

Flat Attachments in an Altered Book

These page images are slightly cropped.  They have not been worked with acrylic paint to the point of work shown in a previous post and may yet change considerably.  This is simply where the pages are now as i work my way through the book.

The attachment above is one of several versions of an Artistamp that was created for another Mail Art Project.  It was created using a digital drawing and painting program – Adobe Photoshop Elements 6, then printed as a photograph.  I’m starting to do this more and more in other works as well so that I can use my own images in collage and mixed media work.


I am not too concerned with the leaf on this page being acidic (and thus damaging to the paper) because it is between two Acrylic Gloss Medium layers.  At this point I’m using Acrylic Gloss Medium as my adhesive and painting over that with a thin layer of diluted gesso when i do not want the surface to be the more slick surface of the Gloss Medium.  I like Gloss Medium as an adhesive because it is archival and transparent.

The attachment here is from a book that was printed in Japanese.  The attached text page was worked separately and then added to this book.  It will most likely be worked more in some way.

I still consider these pages as background or at least not-quite-finished and will probably add to them or at least work them more to some degree.  Of course I’m still rethinking this too.  That is almost always the case as I work – the work evolves as the process continues – which is part of the fun of working of course – to see how it will turn out eventually. 

The book itself and thoughts on Altering a book:

  • The closed hardback book itself is about 5.75 x 8.75 inches.  The pages are slightly smaller.  The workable area of an open spread in this book is about 10 x 8.5 inches.

  • Over Printed Books which are other wise returned to Publishing Houses or Printers to be destroyed – literally thousands a year.  …Although this is probably better now in this age of Printing-On-Demand, Web-Readers and eBooks.

Keeping some of this in mind when choosing a book to alter makes the idea of Altering Books a good and easily obtainable option for unique Journals, Themed Sketchbooks, Sculptures and 3-Dimensional works and all kinds of other creativity.  An Altered Book becomes a one-of-a-kind original work and can most likely last as long as the book itself would, yet with an Altered and Renewed Life.

Haiga ~ Image with Haiku as One Work

  • 8 x 6 Inches @ 300 dpi
  • Digital Drawing and Painting
  • Sketchbook Pro

  • Adobe Photoshop Elements 6 (Digital Chop/Seal stamp only)

Experimenting

This is among my first experiments (okay my 2nd drawing) using the SketchBook Pro for iPad2 app.  The drawing itself was worked entirely in SketchBook Pro.  As I’m not quite up to speed on my desktop computer (intending to upgrade my OS in the next few weeks to months) I have not sync-ed the iP2 with the iMac yet (which should make working an image between one piece of hardware to another quite easy). 

I sent this drawing from the iP2 to my iMac via email.   Then in Photoshop I added the Digital Seal or Chop for this year – which I often use on my digital work. 

I’m experimenting.  At some point I’ll try posting directly to the 19 Planets Art Blog from the iP2, which should by the looks of it, be reasonably easy to do.  …although until I become used to the keyboard I may not be quite as yappity.  I am having fun – and yeah, this is one of the reasons I haven’t been around quite as much as I’d like in the past week or so…

Drawn on an iPad 2 with a Zen Brush app.

Yeah, I’m doing it again – this is more of an illustration/description; either the image illustrates the ku or the ku describes the image. …neither of which is what Haiga should do (imo, as I currently see it).

It’s okay to do this, its just that this isn’t how Haiga is. As I currently understand it, Haiga combines image and haiku into one work, however, both stand on their own and yet also have a relationship – that is not explaining each other. …that is, one is not explaining the other either by image or words.

So, back to working on this – the difference – so that I get Haiga, when I’m actually after Haiga. bwahahahahaha. Life. Again.

Starting in September – Please join us….

Call #1 ~ A Visual And Haiku ~ One a Day for the month of September

This is what I intend to do:  For the month of September I will attempt to create an image and haiku to go together – either as haiga (the two as one image) or separately as haiku with an image – and post at least one a day.

How It Came To Be:  Aubrie Cox (of the Yay Words! Blog) called it Doodle-Ku.  I like what she was doing – a drawing – the doodle – with haiku to go with it.  The idea to try a month of it – one a day, seemed like a good idea to me and possibly for Aubrie too.  September is the month I am going to try to do this.

Personally as far as I’m concerned, how you create your image is up to you, draw, paint, collage, photograph, digital or yeah, however you do it – cool – your own vision, your own version, your own way. I’m easy, as long as it is image and haiku.

Start any time – I will try to start on my last day of August so you will have a place to leave a comment when you post your September 1st Doodle-Ku – or… when ever you do start (when ever you start is okay by me) …and if you miss a day – heck just do one the next day – because that’s what I will do as well.

You are invited to join in – Simply drop me a comment indicating you have posted your Doodle-Ku and I will try to come see it on your blog.

Have Fun. That’s what it’s about too.

lost treasure
the written language
of postal letters

Haiga ~ Image and Haiku as One Work

Digital Drawing and Painting

  • Zen Brush App
  • OldPhotoPro App
  • ArtStudio App
  • iPad 2

The visual look of a hand written letter fascinates me.  After all, alphabet letters are made with line – which is the main element of drawing. Repetition and variation of line along with the quality of line are elements that go into making a good drawing.  Alphabet letters also contain shapes – another important part of drawing.

The same things go on in hand written letters, (notes, manuscripts etc.) that go on in drawings. 

In fact if you can write with a pen or pencil so that someone else can read what you wrote – imo, you can learn to draw just about anything you want to draw – you have the ability to do so.  The control necessary to write a letter of the alphabet is the same kind of control and ability it takes to make a line and shape in a drawing.

I like playing with and exploring this writing-as-drawing concept by “writing” postal (and other) letters using the visual elements I see in letters that use the alphabet.   I create drawing letters without an alphabet so that there is a similarity in the form seen with postal letters. 

The next time you see a hand written note or letter, take a look at it for the beauty of line and shape rather than just the words and alphabet letters you’ve learned to see.   Every hand written letter is unique.  This is part of the treasure I see in hand written letters.  Of course this same concept applies to type although I find hand writing even more interesting.

Other people are aware of this writing-as-drawing of course.  I recently read a post on the CelluloidCook Blog that centered around this same concept – hand writing as drawing.  I’ve used this at times in a variety of ways as well such as the work in the post Don Q and Other Things.

Hand Writing. Treasure. Fun.

  • Zen Brush App

Yes, another play doodle exploration – which is after all what this One-A-Day for September Haiga and Haiku with Image is about of course. It began as I watched the moon among the clouds as they passed in the sky last night.

Wow. Did I mention I’m having a lot of fun using the Apps on my iPad for these dailies in September?  Yeah. A lot of fun. Will I get to exploring on real paper with graphite and inks and colors and other such things for this? …Heck if i know.

Yesterday…. Okay, in the night… I started 21 postcards…

When will I finish them? – Heck if I know.

Will I finish them? – Heck if I know.

Was it fun? – Yeah, it was fun.

The postcards are a response to a Call for Mail Artists and Micropoets I saw echoed on Issa’s Untidy Hut.  The instruction information direct is  from Juliea Joules here.

It felt good to get back into some watercolor and brush on paper exploration. …Even if at this point it is layering for background – something I often do.  I have to start some place when I begin again and that is often where I start – layers and background (although not always…).  

My initial response was to follow the instructions to sit in a chair – a chair that is in each of thirty paintings which are on the instruction site.  As i did this I found I had strong responses to seven different paintings that I wanted to explore.  From those initial explorations I worked on Seven Haiku (an acceptable component of the Call). 

Now there are three watercolor layers on these twenty-one postcards.  My idea is to do three postcards for each haiku I worked on so that I will have a choice of what I might send in as well as inspiration, resource and documentation for future work and my Access Gallery (A gallery i’m working on for my dotcom). I’m hoping to get to another round on these postcards – or at least some of them – tonight.

Fun. Aloha.

It’s fun to spot them in the area.

Digital Photograph

  • 6.5 x 4.5 Inches @ 300 ppi
  • Nikon D80 Digital Camera
  • Adobe Photoshop Elements

 

In Hawaii this bird is called Kolea.  It is also known as the Pacific Golden Plover.  Every year it flies north to Alaska for the summer and every year it flies back to Hawaii for the Winter.  Two flights a year, each of which take about three to four days of Non-stop flying entirely over open ocean and spans about 2,500 miles one way. Yeah, I’d say that’s determination.

Experimenting – Again:

I wanted to see what might be possible for use on a smaller screen with the Zen Brush App. In general with a smaller screen I’d use smaller brush sizes.

Brush sizes in the Zen Brush App I have for the iPad run from 1 to 50, with 10 increments between each of those numbers. …In other words there are 500 brush sizes available. The longer you leave your finger in one place when painting, the larger the area becomes that will be “colored” – similar to the way a real brush might work.

On a small screen the brush sizes from 1 to 10 would probably work well – that’s 100 different sizes.

I do not know if the Zen Brush Apps for the iPhone and iPod are set up exactly the same as the one for the iPad, which is what I have. It’s possible that all 50 sizes may be relatively smaller and so would all work well on the smaller screens.

The “painting” part of the above Haiga was created with the smallest brush size available with the Zen Brush App that I have – the size 1.0 for all 5 brushes.

The brushes are set up with 3 values of dark. – a black, middle value and a light value.

There are then 2 eraser brushes – one that erases entirely and one that erases at about halve (or less) in value. I use these as brushes of course to lighten areas etc.

With the 3 dark-value brushes and the 2 eraser brushes a variety of values can be achieved by repeating strokes.

This is a response to one of Melissa Allen’s haiku that she posted on her Red Dragonfly blog (seed starting).

We have been occasionally collaborating in the sense that I’ve been creating an image when given a subject or theme to respond to without actually having read the haiku the image is intended to be connected with on the blog.

I think we both have been slightly surprised by how well this works at times. Of course, in a sense this is one of the things haiku does – juxtapose two phrase-images that seem unrelated yet upon reflection may be alike in a surprising way. Juxtaposing two works – image and haiku – in a similar way is fun.

Thank you Melissa for allowing me to create in my own way and to play in this way, connected with your haiku. I enjoy doing this a great deal – aloha.

Poem for Your Pocket

fold this poem up
place it in your pocket
carry it with the seasons
watch it from time to time
to see if it ages in beauty

from time to time open it up

snowflakes
become the color of butterflies
each spring

butterfly colors
become the brilliant blossoms
of summer

blossom petals
become the leaves that fall
in the colors of autumn

the colors of autumn
become the light snowflakes
of winter

folding this poem
into your pocket

the seasons of life
blossom

~~

I’ve been working on a chapbook for the month of November, following prompts by Robert Lee Brewer on the Writer’s Digest site. Each day a new prompt.

Occasionally I have other ideas about writing as well. The above work is one of these other ideas. It falls into what I’m beginning to think of as “Doing Poems“. I like the idea although I’m not sure yet where it may be going.

At times I carry photos in my pockets (along with an assortment of other things) to “age” the photos – part of the process I use for artworks on paper, such as collage and mixed media works. It is that process along with the chapbook idea that led me to this thinking of “Doing Poems”.

A note from the Pocket and Doing Poem Series: Explore Self

Digital Drawing and Painting
Walter Foster (Learn To Draw) App
ArtStudio App
ScratchCam App
iPad 2

As I see it every thing we create is an exploration as well as a part of us being our self. Writing, dancing, singing, visual art – creating – these things we do (every thing we do) all become part of our self portrait as an individual as well as this group of beings we call human being. What we do is an illumination of our own being – Our own one unique Life – within the context of our greater being human.

In that sense, I think it’s good to be aware that this is what I am doing. To become aware of this life-being-self that I explore through my art – with that as the dominant focus at times. To remember this as I work. Of course, I particularly enjoy doing this with a sense of fun and humor as elements of being human at times too.

The Walter Foster (Learn To Draw) App is one I recently acquired – it is currently free although you can purchase “additional lessons”. One of the things I like about this app is the way it looks and feels – much like graphite.

I close my eyes
the spin of the universe
increases

Acrylic Backgrounds

Detail – Slightly Cropped Pages

Acrylic on Book Pages

  • Pastedown (the inside cover of the book) and three open-spread pages in the process of being worked as an Altered Book Project.
  • The closed hardback book itself is about 5.75 x 8.75 inches.  The pages are slightly smaller.  The workable area of an open spread in this book is about 10 x 8.5 inches.

Altered Book Projects are embraced by many Mail Art artists.  Books tend to be small enough to easily go through the Postal Service.  Books themselves are a treasure.  Altered Books tend to become even more treasured.

For those new to Altered Books it may initially be a challenge to get past the idea of reworking a book – Yikes! You’re Doing What!?! To A Book?.   If this is similar to your reaction consider some of the books you can choose to give new life:

  • Discarded and Outdated Books of which there are tremendous numbers in existence so that it is likely that an original version can always be found.
  • Damaged and Missing-Page Books that can no longer be read or used functionally as originally intended.
  • Over Printed Books which are other wise returned to Publishing Houses or Printers to be destroyed – literally thousands a year.  …Although this is probably better now in this age of Printing-On-Demand and Web-Readers.

Keeping some of this in mind when choosing a book to alter makes the idea of Altering Books a great and easily obtainable option for unique Journals, Themed Sketchbooks, Sculptures and 3-Dimensional works and all kinds of other creativity.  An Altered Book becomes a one-of-a-kind original work and can most likely last as long as the book itself would, yet with an Altered and Renewed Life.

This image started with the final page of a dream in one of my dream journals that included drawn images from my dreams as well as word descriptions of the dreams. The “bowl” and some of the lines and words in this image are from that journal.

At last count last year I took 8900 plus photos.  That’s more than I usually take in a year. It’s just that I found I liked a lot of things that interested me on my street walks. 

Although I do not wish to encourage the marking of private or public property without prior permission I do find some elements of Graffiti interesting to me.  The painterliness and spontaneity (even when well thought out), the street patina and random juxtaposition, textures, the splatter and slathering of color, the aged, dated, new and wild ideas that come out of a very basic need to create all show up in Graffiti.  There is a lot I like about that spirit.  It’s something I’m finding appealing and want to explore.  This has become something I think about in a lot of ways: Graffiti Mind, the spirit of Graffiti.

street speed

sneakerz change the rulez

secrets

  • Digital Photography
  • Nikon D80 Digital Camera
  • Adobe Photoshop Elements 6

These “Sky Lanterns” were new here this year.   Ever stronger bans and fines and fees on fireworks seem to be generating alternatives.  The ladders (left and right in the photo) are about one third to one quarter the height from a few years ago.  That’s where huge, thick, long coils of firecrackers are suspended and then lit – yeah one big long wow. 

The lanterns are quiet, relatively smokeless and quite awe evoking.  At times I could spot 8 to 10 in the sky in one direction.  They were fascinating to watch.  If they are not banned I suspect the numbers will multiply next time.  They drift with the breeze ever higher and ever farther from the flame heat until out of sight. It was spell binding – and that was fun.

two colts. an April and a May birth now in
January kick up the turf and sand. this near shore
pasture playground for rescued horses and others
that simply need a little extra care. a beautiful care
for a human being to give. because we can give this
to these beautiful creatures. their personality
formed with place and environment as well as the
way they have been treated by the world and other
beings. these two race and prance. they play tag
and nip in a nimble rocking canter. a banter between
them light, challenging and toying to tease each other
on to a faster pace. a race just to feel their own legs
and power, speed and quickness around their grounds,
familiar with confidence in their home and human care
companions.

This Photograph was clicked Friday night (January 20, 2012) in Downtown Honolulu where I attended an Opening for the Clear the Smoke dot Org Photo Project (an awareness project on ways tobacco affects Hawaii and the people of Hawaii using photography as the format) at The Arts at Marks Garage (a center for the Arts located in Downtown Honolulu).  Two photos I had taken on the street were in the Photo Project Show.

The Opening was on “Slow Art Friday” – a night when  you can take your time in Art Galleries and around Downtown to actually see the art. Although I’ve used the words “red maple” (loosely) in this haiku, this is actually a Japanese Maple.   Red Maple leaves are more known for their bright red in autumn.  The leaves on this Japanese Maple are a brilliant red when they first come out and then gradually turn green running through an amazing  range of  red and green on each leaf.  This photo was taken on Friday – February 3, 2012.

Blossom Into the Key

Mixed Media

  • 5 x 7 Inches
  • Acrylic
  • Watercolor
  • Graphite
  • Ink
  • Collage Material (Including – Torn Pages and Digital Drawing and Painting Work Printed as Photographs)

One of several small Mixed Media works centered around Key(s) from 2011. Keys have a tremendous symbolic potential as I see it. I return to them every so often as subject and departure point for work. Among the odds and bits in my studio is a jar full of discarded and found keys – old, rusted, new, shiny and in some cases broken, in a range of materials, colors, shapes and sizes. Taking one out it’s fun to think about what it may unlock, open or start.

Roxie Hanna – of Roxie’s Blog – invited me to appear in a Spotlight interview. My interview response is here.  Roxie is a freelance writer and editor.  Roxie’s Blog is a resource particularly for writers.  She also introduces a variety of Artists and Illustrators along with Poets and other Writers in her Spotlight feature.

Gabrielle of Gabrielle Bryden’s Blog is a writer, poet photographer and advocate of the environment and autism awareness – among other things.  She recently invited me to post as one of her Guest Bloggers with her usual two Questions to respond to in the post. You can see my response here.

Shadow Speak

night filter.  
through my eyes
shadow lingers. beyond the light
shadow sounds. movement fading
into darkness.  drifting through this silence
I become still, listening; the rustle of leaves,
a cricket begins, the distant barking of a dog.
so still this timeless light. deepening
into sleep I dream.

so far away
the ancient night
through leaves

Last night the moon was nearly full and golden in a slightly darkening blue sky.

Following the moon night after night I am amazed by how many different ways it can look in the sky. Yet when I stop to watch it for a while, or for an hour or more, on any one night – wow, how still and present it looks in that moment, as if it is quite capable of holding that one long extended note endlessly. With ease such solid and timeless presence, the moon.

More moon to explore again tonight, again and wow again too.

along the edge of a leaf
haiku

Have a fun look:  A comment becomes a conversation that becomes a post.  Yousei Hime of the  Shiteki Na Usagi blog found interest in an idea as a result of an alternate poetic ground comment here.  After posting National Poetry Month — An Unexpected Poetry Idea the comments and ideas again began to flow. The leaf works in that post are works from 2007 that I updated for that post. 

Saturday I was off island (a term here that usually means on an island other than where you live – although it can mean going to the mainland too).  I spotted plenty of Signature (or Autograph) Trees.  Most of them had been pruned high so the leaves were not reachable. I did find one low enough that I could pluck a leaf – which means more leaves will grow there. Later when I got back to my studio, I wrote on it and then worked the result into this post.  Fun. aloha.

I’m rarely sure exactly where I’m going when I come in to paint.  Although I usually have an idea where I might be heading, I’m okay with letting something that intrigues me take over and I will follow it to find out where it leads me.

Last week I thought I was going to do larger daily bonsai drawings in a larger sketchbook.  After a couple of days I realized the ink was not going to handle the same – different paper.  So I started toying with the idea of adding watercolor to the process.

I prepared some paper and began playing with backgrounds.  That paper was 11 x 7.5 inches.  After deciding to tear/cut a couple of sheets into ATC size paper I found out I actually wanted to do some ATCs. …Which I need to do for some lists I have that happen to include bonsai.  Cool, I thought.

So I did a couple of bonsai ATCs. This is one of them. Today I did two more.  I’m using the sketches I started doing a couple of weeks ago as reference, although I play with it and explore a bit with each ATC I do.

This is the stamp area from one of my Mail Art return envelopes or SASE – Self Addressed, Stamped Envelope.  It was part of the requirement for a group swap with a host. This particular swap in 2006 went through a Mail Art site called Nervousness (or Nness).  The swap itself was for five ATCs (Artist Trading Cards).  

Each participant or “player” who signed up for the swap sent in five ATCs to the host along with their SASE.  

The host swapped out each player’s ATCs into the SASEs of the other players.  Then the envelopes were sent back to a player via their own SASE.  That way each player received five ATCs from other players in return for their own ATCs and the host was not saddle with a lot of postage cost.

Swaps may involve as few as 2 or 3 players or as many as… well… how high do you want to go? 20? 30? Usually swaps have a top limit stated by the host – often this is 10 to 15 so it doesnt get to be too daunting a task to swap all the ATCs out. 

Nervousness is no longer an active Mail Art site.  The membership from that site has drifted in a number of directions including ATCs For All and a sister site Illustrated ATCs.

http://www.atcsforall.com/

http://www.illustratedatcs.com/

ATCs For All is open to everyone at all levels of ability and creativity and the sister site  Illustrated ATCs is a membership-by-jury site (to join you submit samples of your work).  

On my envelope I included a stamp that I had designed and then made into legal postage.  It’s the blue stamp. It is from a watercolor I did called Touching Stars.  

For the swap we were asked to add double postage to our SASEs to ensure envelopes returned without a postage problem. This is because some ATCs can be heavy when a lot of embellishment work is added. 

I like to add real stamps to my envelopes, both too a swap partner or host and on SASEs. This is because I like stamps, as do most Mail Art artists.  I like to collect stamps with the entire cancellation marks included.  Those marks are often as interesting as the stamps.  

Often I keep the entire envelope from a swap, sometimes just the stamp area however I’m careful to include the entire cancellation mark and a good portion of the envelope.  When I have duplicate stamps (the same stamp on two different envelopes) I sometimes use one of them as collage material on another ATC or in other artwork. 

Frequently Mail Art artists add notes to envelopes to help hosts keep track of what should go in the envelope or what should be coming when you receive the envelope.  On this envelope I did that as well.

The first line of my note means a 5 for 5 swap with an open theme (in other words each artist decides what they will make for their ATC).  Some swaps have a theme – such as a subject like Birds or maybe even more specifically Crows or Haiku, it might simply be a color for the theme such as Blue. The host will state this in the sign up call. 

The second line of my note means it’s an ATC swap and who the envelope belongs too (in this case my name as known on Nness was Wrick) and the site that the swap was going through – Nervousness. 

The “DO” in the upper left was added by the host – it said Do Not Bend.  I suspect this was added because I had folded the envelope so it could be placed in my original envelope that was sent to the host.  

When I open envelopes I often open them on the non-stamp end so I can make sure I keep the stamp area intact.  That is what I did with the above envelope. 

Two more mail art swap envelopes (prior to sending them so there are no cancellation marks – yet):

Both of these envelopes have been painted (on the backs there are drawings and more paint as well).  Each has a self made valid postage stamp – the yellow blossoms.  Each also has an embellishing stamp that I have made as well. 

Mail Art envelopes are fun to find in your mail box.  Not all are as elaborate as these – some are more elaborate of course too.  Some are very much like any other envelope. They all make it fun to go to your mail box though. Have fun. Aloha.

Altered Scanner Photograph

  • 8 x 12 Inches @ 300 ppi
  • Epson Perfection V300 Photo Scanner
  • Adobe Photoshop Elements 6

These are bottle brush (tree) branches.  The tree grows in my yard.  Sometimes I let it grow because I can make use of the long slender branches on various projects (art and garden among other uses).  

When I trim the tree back I save branches of varying lengths and diameters that I think I may want to use.  Sometimes I cut and carve ring patterns into the bark as I’ve done here. The project I had intended for these particular branches ran into some complications and I have not use them – yet.

I’ve had these branches in this state for some time now and I like the way they feel/look. I may yet use them in some project of course.  

Here I’ve made use of them in another way by photographing them with my scanner. This is called scanner photography and I’ve combined the image with haiku to create haiga.

I like to scan objects with some depth as well as texture. When I select a scanner I look for one that has some depth to the area of focus (depth of field) for exactly this purpose.

The depth of field on scanners is quite shallow. Some are less than an eighth of an inch. Some are three quarters of an inch or more. The mechanism of a scanner to capture an image is similar but slightly different from the mechanism of a digital camera to capture an image. It is very specific. Scanners are very limited in the depth of field area but they have a good size surface area that can be in focus. The clarity of that focus can be quite sharp.

Occasionally I find a card on the ground.  There is a lot of mystery around that kind of card.  How did it get there?  Why did it become there? Things like that.

There are also a lot of places those cards take me.  Or maybe I follow them back to where they might have been. 

I pick them up – after photographing them in place – as I did with this card.  

My desk and all the surfaces around me are full of such meaningless stuff with significance.

This card is now on my desk, to the side, just above my keyboard. It is weighted down with a rectangular and broken piece of stone tile I found on the same walk.  I wonder where the stone for this tile came from too.  It’s not from the islands. The tile is about 1 x 2 inches and broken on one of the short sides. 

Yeah, I do things like this.  I think things like this too.

A beautiful soft rain is falling. 

I like that.

This is an alternate version of the same stamp.  With this version I may actually be able to make a valid domestic (for use within the USA only) postal stamp.  I have not submitted it so I do not know if it would clear the regulations.  

One of the regulations is that a denomination can not be placed on the stamp design itself (because the stamp can be made into a number of different denominations).  That is why I have changed the 5¢ amount to the star.  

On an actual stamp the perforation cuts would not be quite like this either depending on where the stamp was made.

 A Reminder:

For September 2012: The 2nd Annual 30 Days of Haiga

Would you like to join in the month of haiga? Please join in as often as you are able to do so and invite your friends; especially those who create and enjoy haiga...

In September I will attempt to create and post at least one haiga per day for the entire month. I may or may not succeed however the fun is in trying. Please join me as often as you are able to do so.

 No sign-up is required. Simply post your own original haiga that you create for that day: the idea being to create at least one new haiga and post it each day.

 Would you like another way for others to be able to find your haiga? Post in a comment on my blog for the day you create your haiga and add the link URL for your haiga to your comment.

 Take a look at what others do and comment – about what you see or like in their haiga – or what the work makes you think of in your own experience or a memory the work brings up for you. You can of course even story if it comes to you via the haiga.

 The bottom line is of course to have fun creating haiga in your own way and learning how others create too.

The List of Going Home

 

 

again a strap of scented leather

in the triangle I begin to wander

again to gather fronds and feathers

to attach with thumbs and fingers

 

far away near a yellow monastery

another temple eccentric genius

paints away red silent demons

a vacant overflowing flowered soul

 

a ritual numbering my steps correct  

my ancient skull crunching numbers 

closer to these hospital beds I sleep

my walking dream begins to follow

 

down a path I’ve once barely taken

another strutting vendor on display

the sympathy of cards and flowers

silent faces crossing flash and glitter

 

surgically I step between the stones

singing as I slouch along the path

today I limped again into the distant

sound and song of going home

55 Short Stories is a form of Nano Fiction or sometimes also called Flash Writing. Essentially it is a story with all the characteristics of a short story – characters, plot, setting etc. it is limited to 55 words or less (although some calls specify 55 words exactly). The title is not included in the word count, however it is limited to 7 words – or less. I just find it fun to attempt them.

Sketchbook Drawing

Three Variations - Altered Sketchbook Drawing

Metaphysical Space

Digital Mixed Media – Three Variations

  • 3.5 x 6 Inches Each

The original sketchbook ink drawing is from 1996/97.  One of a number of images that play with the concept of layering enigmatic space on a two-dimensional surface.  It’s fun to return to this concept periodically.  The three altered variations were created with digital technology.  One of the great advantages with digital technology is the almost endless variations possible to explore when altering a work.

The September 9 Prompt: Passion Fruit and/or Peaches

This passion fruit vine is currently growing in my orchid closet. It’s been there in a pot since last January when a friend gave it to me. My current plan is to plant it in November – as it will probably be easier to keep it well water after that for a while. 

I’m having fun looking into haiga others are creating this month.  My haiga today is a result of looking at one of Angie Werren’s haiga as well as having seen the diversity of what other people are doing. I like that.  It seemed to me I wasnt pushing my images in nearly as many ways as I could. So I tried some things in a little different way for today. Fun. Thank you Angie and all who are playing and exploring. Go for it and join in – it’s fun.

The September 14 Prompt: A Band of Stars 

Over the last couple of years on my walks i’ve been photographing imprints, writings, blossoms and other things on and in sidewalks where ever I go.  One day I was photographing drawings and words that had been left in the cement curb in front of a house about two blocks from where I live.

The owner of the house came out and asked if I knew who those people were whose work I was photographing. No, I hadn’t really gotten to the names yet.

The following was then related to me by the current owner of the house:

Sometime in the mid 1960’s The Beatles came to Hawaii and stayed for several weeks.  They liked Kailua (which is where I now live). George and John stayed in one house and Paul and Ringo stayed in another house.  The two houses were on opposite sides of Kailua town. The guys then went back and forth to party and – yeah, have fun. 

While The Beatles were here the city began to pour the sidewalk and curbing in front of the house where Paul and Ringo were staying.  Seeing this, the two came out and played in the fresh cement. You can read their names – Paul signed Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr signed just Ringo – with his mark – an X through the O of his name – making that the Starr. 

A few years ago the city came through and redid the corner curbing and walks of most streets in the area to accommodate wheelchairs and strollers and so on, and now most of what The Beatles did in the cement is torn up and gone. Two names remain in the curbing next to each other, Paul McCartney and Ringo with the X-in-the-O Starr.  

When the curbing and walks were being replaced the owners of the house asked if they could keep a large chunk of the cement that was being hauled away – which had a number of drawings and words on it. That chunk of history now rests under a tree in their front yard a few feet from the sidewalk. 

It’s fun to walk by that place and listen to The Beatles on my iPod now. It makes me smile to know they would play in the fresh cement – just like hundreds of other kids around here – just having fun.
